(X. Li), (Z. Tang) Facing soaring global energy demand and intensifying environmental problems, the search for sustainable energy alternatives has become imperative. The efficient conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2), one of the primary greenhouse gases, plays the crucial role in mitigating global climate change. The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) provides an effective solution for its conversion into high-value-added chemicals, promoting the development of the carbon cycle and green chemistry. Porous materials of distinctive physicochemical properties have demonstrated substantial potential in eCO2RR. In this review, various strategies of porousizing catalysts for boosted eCO2RR are briefly summarized. Subsequently, the functionalities of porous materials including enrichment effect, modulating microenvironmental pH, stabilizing key species, facilitating mass transfer and tuning the nature of active sites to improve the efficiency and selectivity of eCO2RR are categorized. Furthermore, we discuss the principal challenges confronting current electrocatalytic systems and propose future research directions. Insights from this review are expected to benefit broad communities of chemical and material research for rationalizing porous electrocatalysts and optimizing eCO2RR performances. Graphical Abstract We summarized the functional roles of porous catalysts in electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reactions (eCO2RR). Additionally, the future trends of porous catalysts and technologies in eCO2RR are discussed. Keywords Porous nanomaterials Electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction Enrichment Local pH Mass transfer 1 Introduction The past decades witness the rocketing global greenhouse gas emissions to a historic high amount, with an annual emission of CO2 up to 54 billion tons, garnering worldwide attention for urgent action [1,2]. The most pressing issue is how we can effectively reduce and mitigate the detrimental impacts of CO2 emission. A feasible strategy is to transition CO2 to value-added chemicals [3–10], such as carbon monoxide (CO), formic acid (HCOOH), methane (CH4), methanol (CH3OH), ethylene (C2H4), acetic acid (CH3COOH), ethanol (C2H5OH), ethane (C2H6), and propanol (C3H7OH), etc. Therefore, researchers have tried various methods applicable to CO2 conversion, such as electrocatalysis [11–15], photocatalysis [16–18], thermal catalysis [19–21], and biocatalysis [22,23], etc. Among them, electrocatalytic CO2 conversion driven by the electricity stored from renewable energy sources like wind and solar energy preferred thanks to the economic feasibility and environmental sustainability [24]. As for eCO2RR, researchers have invested substantial efforts into the design and synthesis of novel catalysts, the optimization of electrolyzer configurations and the refinement of operating conditions. On one hand, the exploration of efficient catalysts can reduce the energy barrier of eCO2RR and improve the selectivity of specific product. On the other hand, the design of flow cell or membrane electrode assembly (MEA) electrolyzer [25,26], as well as the optimization of the composition and concentration of electrolyte, may further enhance the electrocatalytic performance at large current density and long operating duration. Studies on eCO2RR have made significant progress but are still far behind expectations for practical applications. First, the reaction mechanism of eCO2RR involves a complex multistep process of electron-proton transfer, hence the stability of each reaction intermediate on the electrode surface is critical for the product selectivity [27]. Second, carbonates formed during the reaction process are prone to deposit on the electrode surface, cover active sites and thereby weaken catalytic effectiveness. Third, the high overpotential of eCO2RR and competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) pose obstacles to industrial applications [28]. Last but not least, industry-relevant eCO2RR requires operation at high current density and the consequent large potential imposes stringent requirements on the stability of catalysts. To address these challenges, it needs to develop stable eCO2RR catalysts that effectively drive the conversion of CO2 in selective and specific manners. The structure and active sites of catalysts must be delicately designed to ensure efficient adsorption, activation, and conversion of CO2 molecules, while effectively inhibiting unnecessary reactions such as HER [29,30]. Porousizing catalysts have been recognized as one of the most powerful strategies due to the embedded higher number of catalytic active sites and larger specific surface area gifted by the pore structures [31,32]. Such pore structures facilitate the enrichment and confinement of intermediates, thereby promoting C–C coupling to produce high-value chemicals [33,34]. The pore structure results in a higher local pH, which can inhibit HER. Moreover, catalysts with porosity benefit mass transfer processes by providing unique transport pathways for reactant molecules to promote catalytic performance [35,36]. These characteristics of porous nanomaterials render an outstanding micro-reactor platform to obtain high-value-added products through eCO2RR (Fig. 1 ). In this regard, this review aims to summarize the recent advances in porous catalysts for eCO2RR, highlighting key developments in mechanism exploration. We introduce different synthetic methods of porous catalysts. Furthermore, we discuss the functionalities of various porous catalysts including porous metals, porous supports and porous layer modification in facilitating eCO2RR (Fig. 2 ). Based on the progress made in this field, we provide insights into the design of efficient catalysts for eCO2RR. These insights will be helpful to overcome the current problems encountered in eCO2RR and approach the actual demands for CO2 conversion into high-value-added products. 2 Design and synthesis of porous catalysts The controllable synthesis of porous catalysts is the prerequisite for elucidate the promotion effect of pore structures in eCO2RR. Template method and template-free method are two typical synthesis strategies for porous materials [35,37]. Based on the spatial arrangement of pores, porous catalysts can be classified into ordered and disordered ones. The catalysts of regular aperture arrangement, such as honeycomb, array, and so on, are generally prepared by the template method [38]. While, the catalysts of irregular pore arrangement are easily obtained by template-free method [39]. In addition, porous materials that lack catalytic activity could be utilized as supports or modification layers. Combining eCO2RR catalysts with porous nanomaterials is expected to maintain the original catalytic reaction process and also exploit the unique advantages of porous structures [40]. 2.1 Template method The template method is the widely used approach for the preparation of porous structures, utilizing specific templates to guide or constrain the growth of catalysts and thus obtain the regularly arranged and ordered pore structure [41]. The template method can be divided into hard template method and soft template method [42]. The hard template method is used rigid templates to form pore structures, such as polymer microspheres and silica microspheres. Subsequent removal of the hard template by chemical treatment results in the formation of ordered porous nanomaterials. Using the hard template method allows for precise control of the size, shape and distribution of pores by selecting appropriate template compositions and preparation conditions. The soft template method typically employs the assemblies of amphiphilic surfactant molecules that primarily comprise various ordered structures [43,44]. These soft templates include liquid crystals, vesicles, micelles, microemulsions, membranes, and self-organized structures of biomolecules and polymers, etc. [45]. The shape, size and orientation of pores are controlled by the mesoscopic dimensions as well as the hydrophilic and lipophilic regions. The porous catalysts are achieved via the template material solidification and the subsequent removal of templates [46]. 2.2 Template-free method The template-free method that does not rely on any template materials produces an irregular spatial arrangement of pores through processes such as etching [47,48], thermal treatment [49], de-alloying [50,51] and etc. In the process of preparing porous catalysts using acid etching, surface atoms or ions of particles interact with hydrogen ions in the etching solution, giving rise to the formation of soluble compounds. The porous catalysts are fabricated by controlling the etching conditions and process parameters, such as concentration, temperature and duration. Alternatively, the thermal treatment method works by heating a precursor mixture under controlled conditions. The dealloying is another effective method for obtaining high-porosity metal particles. This technique involves selective removal of one component from an alloy system to form the pore networks, which retain the mechanical stability offered by the remaining metal or metalloid component. The morphology and porosity of resulting materials can be tailored by adjusting the dealloying condition. 2.3 Loading eCO2RR catalysts on porous supports Porous supports include metal oxide (CeO2, TiO2, and SnO2, etc.) [52,53], non-metal materials (SiO2, and carbon, etc.) [54-56], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [49‒51], covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [57,58], and so on. Loading catalytic metal single atoms, molecules and nanoparticles into porous supports would enhance the exposure of active sites and optimize the local condition of eCO2RR, thereby improving the catalytic performance [59]. Typically, a two-step method is adopted, which first involves synthesizing a porous support followed by loading the catalysts into these pores. Beyond that, MOFs are a class of porous materials formed through the coordination of metal ions or clusters with organic ligands [40]. The judicious selection of metals and organic linkers enables tunability of pore size and shape in MOFs [60]. They not only serve as supports for catalysts but also act as precursors. When used as precursors, MOFs are thermally treated at high temperatures to form porous carbon catalysts that inherit their porous structure, while simultaneously creating highly dispersed metal active sites. 2.4 Porous layer modification of eCO2RR catalysts To control the reaction near the electrode surface, the scientists modified the catalyst surface with polymers, organic ligands and hybrid organic-inorganic layers to suppress HER and facilitate eCO2RR [61]. Recognizing the high porosity and structural modularity of COFs [62] and MOFs [63], they have been utilized for precisely tuning of the catalytic process without altering the intrinsic properties of active catalytic sites. This structure is usually grown epitaxially on the electrode surface by linking metals to ligands. 3 Mechanism of electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction The metal catalysts used in eCO2RR are extremely diverse, and CO2 can be reduced to various products on different metals [64]. Au, Ag, Zn, Pd and Ga benefit the formation of CO as the dominant product, while Pb, Hg, Tl, In, Sn, Cd and Bi promote the formation of HCOOH. Beyond CO and HCOOH as the C1 products, Cu is recognized as the only metal sporting a propensity for producing hydrocarbons and alcohols with more than one carbon atoms (C2+ products) in eCO2RR. In the eCO2RR process, an applied electric field provides the primary energy and water supplies the source of hydrogen ions, for the conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals [65]. In general, the eCO2RR process involves multiple steps: adsorption and activation of CO2 on the catalyst surface, proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) between the intermediates and catalyst, and formation and desorption of the products. The adsorption and activation of CO2 on the catalyst surface is a prerequisite for subsequent reduction steps [66]. Previous studies have shown that CO2 molecules undergo chemical adsorption and activation on the active sites of the catalyst surface, primarily through three possible modes. In the first mode, the carbon atom in CO2 serves as the attachment point to form a carbon coordination with the catalyst surface. In the second mode, the oxygen atoms in CO2 that possess lone pair electrons act as the donor to the Lewis acid centers on the catalyst surface, forming an oxygen-coordinated interaction. For the last, one carbon atom and one oxygen atom of CO2 feature a mixed coordination with the catalyst surface. After CO2 molecules are adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, charge transfer occurs between CO2 and the catalyst, activating CO2 into a partially charged CO2 − species to proceed the subsequent steps. 3.1 Mechanism of C1 products formation in eCO2RR The major C1 products formed via eCO2RR include CO, CH3OH, HCOOH or formate (HCOO−), and CH4. As shown in Fig. 3 , the protonation of CO2 to form *COOH and *OCHO is the first step of reaction pathways for C1 products in eCO2RR [67]. Then, the *OCHO is further transformed into HCOO− or HCOOH. In the other pathway, an electron transfer removes a molecule of water from *COOH to form *CO. At the catalytic site with weak adsorption of *CO, CO is then generated through *CO desorption. When the catalytic site has strong adsorption of *CO, *CO is further transformed into *CHO or *COH, and finally generates CH4, CH3OH and HCHO. 3.2 Mechanism of C2+ products formation in eCO2RR The popular C2+ products formed via eCO2RR include C2H5OH, CH3COOH, C2H4 and C3H7OH. The key to the formation of multi-carbon products is the C–C coupling step, namely, the intermediate species are coupled and then the reaction pathway through multiple PCET or other steps determines the formation of multi-carbon product [68]. There are many discussions about the specific process of C–C coupling, and the possible mechanisms is divided into three categories [69]: (1) *CO dimerization to generate *COCO; (2) *CO conversion to *COH or *CHO followed by coupling with another *CO to form *COCO(H); (3) *CO conversion to *COH or *CHO that couples to generate *CO(H)CO(H). In the CO2 conversion process, these intermediates undergo further hydrogenation to generate various C2+ products [70]. The ability of catalysts to form and stabilize *CO, as well as to facilitate C–C coupling, are the primary factors influencing the reaction pathway. 4 Function of porous catalysts in eCO2RR 4.1 Enrichment effect It is widely recognized that *CO serves as a crucial intermediate in Cu-based catalysts for the generation of products, and its coverage on the catalyst surface determines the likelihood of C–C coupling [71,72]. Huang et al. [73] observed that the energy barrier of *CO intermediate dimerization was lowered with higher *CO coverage on Cu surfaces. Therefore, to promote the performance of C2+ products in eCO2RR, utilizing the porous catalysts to enrich *CO intermediates is a feasible strategy. For instance, Han et al. [74] used the spherical micelles of amphiphilic block copolymer polystylene-block-poly(oxyethylene) (PS-b-PEO) as the soft template to synthesize mesoporous Cu electrodes. As shown in Fig. 4(a) , the positively charged (Cu(H2O)6)2+ ions were spontaneously aggregated in the exterior hydrophilic PEO regions of the spherical micelle in a mixed solvent of water and tetrahydrofuran (THF). A self-supporting Cu film cathode was obtained by applying a constant reduction potential to induce Cu film deposition on the Cu foam, and then removing the polymer template repeatedly with THF. By altering the solvent ratio and molecular weight of the block copolymer, four types of porous Cu catalysts were obtained with different pore sizes of 20, 40, 60 and 80 nm, respectively. With the pore size decreased, the performance of catalyst in eCO2RR was improved, achieving an ethylene Faraday efficiency (FE) of 85.6% and a constant current density of 368 mA cm−2 with a pore size of 20 nm (S-Cu20) in MEA (Fig. 4(b)). To demonstrate the origin of nanocavity in enriching intermediates and enhancing C–C coupling, in situ Raman (Figs. 4(c) and 4(d)) and finite-element method (FEM) simulation (Figs. 4(e) and 4(f)) were employed. The results showed that the enrichment of *CO intermediates and the increase of *CO coverage were conducive to the production of C2H4. Density functional theory (DFT) further explained that increasing *CO coverage decreased the energy barrier of two *CO dimerization into *OCCO, which was the key intermediate of C2H4 formation (Fig. 4(g)). As for the multi-shell catalyst, the porous structure plays a more prominent role in enriching intermediates, which alters the product selectivity. For example, Xiao et al. [75] described a strategy to enhance the yield of C2+ product formation in eCO2RR by utilizing the spatial confinement effect. First, a FEM simulation was used to explore the effect of the number of shells on the concentration of C1 and C2+ products (Figs. 5(a) and 5(b)). As shown in Fig. 5(c), the ratio of C2+/C1 increased with the increase in the number of shells, where the expected C2+/C1 ratio of 5-shell catalysts reached 10.1. Guided by the simulation result, a series of hollow multi-shell Cu2O catalysts were synthesized by using hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) multilamellar vesicles as the soft templates. As expected, the experimental results showed that as the number of shells increased, the hollow multi-shell Cu catalysts exhibited substantially improved selectivity toward C2+ products. Specifically, the 4.4-shell catalyst achieved a maximum C2+ FE of over 80% at 900 mA cm−2. In situ electrochemical attenuated total reflectance surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) was used to monitor the surface *CO intermediates during the eCO2RR process (Figs. 5(d) and 5(e)). The 4.4-shell Cu had a higher coverage of linearly bound CO at an atop site (*COatop) and stronger interaction with *COatop compared to the commercial Cu particles (Fig. 5(f)). In brief, the introduction of porous shells induces the spatial confinement effect, enhance the CO-CO coupling step and promote the formation of C2+ products. Due to the complex formation paths of C2+ products, the porous structure is able to enrich other intermediates beside *CO intermediates [49,76]. The size and morphology of the cavity affect the enrichment effect, which would determine the selectivity of products in eCO2RR. Zhang et al. [49] synthesized three porous CuO nanoplate catalysts with different pore sizes through heat treatment and controlled annealing time to achieve highly selective ethanol production, demonstrating a high ethanol FE of 44% at an ethanol partial current density of ~500 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6(a) ). A volcanic-like relationship between the OH− concentration of porous CuO nanoplate catalyst and the size of nanocavity was found within the range of 0−20 nm, indicating that the selection of pore size could regulate the enrichment intensity (Fig. 6(c)). As shown in Fig. 6(b), non-covalent interaction enhanced the C−O bond in *CHCOH, elevating the energy barrier for C–O bond scission in *CCH, thus inhibiting ethylene dehydration. The experimental evidence, DFT calculation and COMSOL simulation (Fig. 6(d)) revealed that the increased coverage of *OH associated with the nanocavity size-dependent confinement effect contributed to high ethanol selectivity. In brief, increasing the coverage of *OH could promote the non-covalent interaction and the hydrogenation of *CHCOH to *CHCHOH. This discovery helps to improve the selectivity of ethanol and further demonstrates the beneficial role played by the porous structure. In addition to the advantages discussed above, porous nanomaterials also regulate the behavior of C–C coupling by enriching intermediate. Cai et al. [77] synthesized self-pressurized nanoscale capsule catalysts, which consisted several catalyst nanoparticles wrapped in a permeable shell, and the shell was composed of poly(ether-block-amide) trapped in a mesoporous carbon framework. Because the diffusion of the molecules was related to the “like dissolves like” principle, the polar CO2 molecules and liquid products could freely pass the polar shell, while CO is blocked by self-pressurized nanoscale capsule catalysts due to weak polarity [78,79]. The study showed that the CO pressure of the nano-sized capsule catalyst could reach 8±3 bar. In contrast to the traditional two-step cascade reaction (CO2 to CO and CO–CO coupling to C2+), the study identified a CO–CO2 coupling path that directly converted CO2 to acetate and propanol with FE of 38.5 ± 2.2% and 25.7 ± 1.2%, respectively. It provided a new idea for the development of the structure-activity relationship inside the porous materials for the eCO2RR process. The porous structure may enrich cations, especially alkali metal cations, which affect the eCO2RR through multiple mechanisms [80]. These mechanisms include changing the interfacial electric field strength, stabilizing the reaction intermediates, affecting the local concentration of CO2, regulating the activity of HER, etc. [81]. For instance, K+ cations enhance the adsorption of *COOH intermediate from CO2 and promote the formation of CO [82]. The presence of K+ cation stabilizes the *CO intermediate by increasing electron density, favoring its further conversion rather than direct desorption to CO [83, 84]. In one word, the high concentration of cations helps to improve the stability of intermediate, which would be realized using the porous structure. Ma et al. [85] designed the electrochemically reduced porous Cu nanosheet (ER-CuNS) and flat Cu nanosheet (F-CuNS) to investigate the effect of K+ ions on the performance of eCO2RR (Fig. 7(a) ). A high FE of 83.7 ± 1.4% and large partial current density of 0.56 ± 0.02 A cm−2 for C2+ products were achieved in strong acid (pH ≤ 1), and the FE of hydrogen was less than 10% (Fig. 7(b)). Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurement displayed that the concentration of K+ on ER-CuNS was 4.5 times higher than that of F-CuNS. The FEM simulation uncovered that the higher concentration of K+ was stabilized within ER-CuNS, resulting from the amplification of the electric field near the pore site (Figs. 7(c) and 7(d)). The DFT calculation concluded that K+ significantly promoted CO2 activation and *CO formation through strengthening adsorption of COOH* intermediate on the Cu surface. Further analysis on the charge density indicated that K+ increased the total electron density of *COOH intermediate, leading to the stabilization of *COOH intermediate on the catalyst surface and ultimately reducing the energy barrier of C–C coupling. 4.2 Modulating microenvironmental pH Owing to the porous materials of cavity and channel structures that contribute to the formation of a highly alkaline microenvironment near the catalyst surface, properly designed porous catalysts could play a crucial role in inhibiting HER and converting CO2. Feng et al. [86] demonstrated that combining microenvironment modulation by porous channel structure promoted efficient eCO2RR to C2+ products in acidic electrolyte (pH ≤ 1). They synthesized the La-doped Cu hollow sphere (La Cu HS) catalyst with the porous channel structure in shell through a facile two-step approach (Fig. 8(a) ). Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherm experiments confirmed that La-Cu HS had a mesoporous structure of 5 nm. FEM simulation and in-situ surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) were employed to verify the pH values of the electrolyte near the surface of hollow spheres and solid spheres as well as in the channels of hollow spheres under different current. The pH value of hollow spheres with channels was always higher than that of solid spheres (Figs. 8(b) and 8(c)). Over the entire current density range, the H2 FE of La-Cu HS was suppressed to less than 10%. This hollow spheres with a porous channel structure contributed to the formation of a highly alkaline microenvironment near the catalyst surface, which exhibited a C2+ products FE of 86.2% with a partial current density of −775.8 mA cm−2. In addition to the single cavity structure mentioned above, three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical pore structures and special transmission channels are expected to enable the electrolytes within the pores or cavities to easily achieve a high local pH. Zhao et al. [62] coated porous COFs on Cu catalyst with immobilized perfluorinated sulfonic acid (PFSA) achieving a FE of 75% for C2+ products at −200 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9(a) ). The result of diffusion-reaction simulation showed that imine and carbonyl-functionalized COFs regulated the ionomer structure to confine the proton transport to the hydrophilic nanochannels, resulting in high local alkalinity to facilitate C–C coupling. (Figs. 9(b) and 9(c)). Nguyen-Phan et al. [87] prepared a hierarchical CuO-derived inverse opal (CuO-IO) catalyst with an average pore size of 185 nm by template method (Fig. 9(d)), which had high CO selectivity in eCO2RR and less HER (Figs. 9(e) and 9(f)). 3D ordered macropore (3DOM) structure promoted the eCO2RR by creating a local pH gradient within the catalyst pores that depleted the local concentration of available protons for hydrogen evolution. 4.3 Stabilizing key species Previous studies have suggested that the pre-oxidation of Cu might greatly enhance catalytic performance for the formation of C2+ products, and such improvement is attributed to the presence of active Cu+ species in eCO2RR [88]. Furthermore, theoretical calculation indicated that Cu+ species collaborated with Cu0 species to facilitate CO2 activation and C−C coupling, thereby promoting the production of multi-carbon products [89]. Unfortunately, the active Cu+ species is easily reduced back to Cu0 under eCO2RR operating conditions, which affects C−C coupling [48,90]. The unique cavity structure of porous materials may be used to inhibit the loss of carbon intermediates adsorbed on the active sites, thereby stabilizing Cu+ species [70]. For example, Yang et al. [48] prepared three types of Cu2O catalysts by acid etching: multi-hollow, solid and fragmental Cu2O (Fig. 10(a) ). At a potential of −0.61 V (vs. RHE), multi-hollow Cu2O produced C2+ compounds with a FE up to 75.2 ± 2.7% at a partial current of −267 ± 13 mA cm−2. The multi-hollow catalyst exhibited a large C2+/C1 products ratio of 7.2, which was 9 and 8 times higher than that of solid Cu2O and fragmental Cu2O, respectively. In sharp contrast to solid and fragmental counterparts, the multi-hollow Cu2O retained the Cu+ characteristic Raman mode (Raman peaks at 223, 419, 524, and 624 cm−1) even after 20 min in eCO2RR, which proved that the Cu+ components in the multi-hollow Cu2O catalyst were well preserved (Figs. 10(b)−(d)). The evolution of Cu K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) with reaction time was tracked and a linear combination fitting was performed to quantitatively determine the amount of Cu+ retained. After 20 min of reaction, the calculated Cu+ species content was maintained at 32.1% in the multi-hollow Cu2O, which was consistent with the Raman observation. All these results suggested that the pores were effective in protecting locally Cu+ sites from reduction during eCO2RR and promoting the formation of C2+ products. Furthermore, some studies have proved that the porous structure is not easily eroded by electrolytes and other substances in the cavity, so the cavity would offer the active interfaces to stabilize Cu+ and other species. Li et al. [91] synthesized amorphous CuSiO3 coated on ordered porous CuO (p-CuSiO3/CuO) catalyst for eCO2RR. The porous heterostructure stabilized the Cu+ active site and reduced the adsorption energy of the key C2 intermediate. The p-CuSiO3/CuO achieved a C2+ products FE of 91.7% at −400 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte. 4.4 Facilitating mass transfer and diffusion Since the reactants, products and transport are usually carried out through the interparticle space and the three-phase boundary (TPB) that are typically confined to the catalyst surface, the nanostructure of catalysts plays an important role in the mass transfer and TPB construction [92]. The porous material could tune the mass transfer, making it promising for eCO2RR. Li et al. [51] fabricated a porous Cu catalytic layer by co-sputtering deposition of Cu and Al followed by dealloying. The porous electrode could promote the transmission of gas through the interface between the electrode and electrolyte at high current density. The CO2/pure water co-electrolysis delivered a C2H4 partial current density of 420 mA cm−2 at a low full cell voltage of 3.54 V and without the use of any liquid electrolyte (Figs. 11(a) and 11(b)). In addition, Zhang et al. [93] prepared Cu2O inverse opals (Cu-IOs) structure on FTO glass with an average pore size of 340 nm using polystyrene (PS) as the template (Fig. 11(c) and 11(d)). The Cu-IOs catalyst reduced CO2 to CO and HCOOH with the FE of 45.3% and 33.6%, which was 3 times and 5 times than that of Cu particles under the same condition. The increase of FE was ascribed to the greatly improved diffusion of reactants in the interconnected porous structure (Fig. 11(e)). Wettability, as a fundamental physical phenomenon at the solid-liquid interface, is crucial in eCO2RR. It dictates the affinity between the electrode surface and electrolyte, thereby influencing the concentration distribution of *H intermediates and CO2 at TPB [94]. On hydrophilic electrode surfaces, the coverage by the aqueous solution effectively accumulates *H intermediates, thus promoting hydrogen generation. In contrast, hydrophobic surfaces partially repel the aqueous solution, providing more space for the diffusion of CO2, thereby facilitating the transfer of CO2 molecules and carbon-based intermediates on the catalyst surface [95,96]. Utilizing porous structure to modulate wettability might improve the diffusion of the reactants, thereby enhancing the reaction rate. For example, Geng et al. [42] synthesized a series of porous Cu2O spheres with similar particle sizes but different pore sizes (140, 240 and 340 nm) by using a wet chemical method (Figs. 12(a) −(c)). The hydrophobic channels not only facilitated rapid CO2 transport but also captured compressed CO2 bubbles, forming a rich and stable TPB, which allowed for the electrolysis of large amounts of CO2 at high current density (Fig. 12(d)). The hydrophobic porous Cu catalyst with 240 nm pore size demonstrated the highest efficiency in converting CO2 to C2+ products, achieving an FE of 75.3% and a current density of −753 mA cm−2 (Fig. 12(e)). By using the concave active site, the surface hydrophobicity of the hole was endowed, and the difference of hydrophobicity of different pore sizes was realized (Fig. 12(f)). The results of in situ spectroscopy and DFT calculation proved that the atomic edge of the concave surface of porous Cu2O catalyst promoted the C−C coupling through the energy-favorable *OC-COH pathway, leading to C2+ formation. Furthermore, by mimicking biological surfaces in nature with special wettability, such as lotus leaves or butterfly wings, porous materials can be designed with similar microstructures. Zhang et al. [97] prepared a bioinspired SnO x nanoporous electrode that mimicked the lotus surface structure to promote gasphilicity. In CO2-saturated electrolyte, the electrode film exhibited a “plastron” TPB that optimized the capture and reduction of CO2 bubbles (Fig. 12(g)). This structure increased the concentration of CO2, accelerated the mass transfer rate, and significantly improved the selectivity of eCO2RR to CO and formic acid (FEC1 ~90%), and inhibited HER (FE < 5%). The regulation of these surface properties was of significant importance for enhancing the catalytic efficiency and selectivity of eCO2RR. 4.5 Tuning the nature of active sites In addition to the above unique properties, porous nanomaterials have been widely used as supports of metal active centers, such as single metal atoms [92,93], nanoparticles [53,98] and molecular catalysts [99]. Positioning active sites in a microenvironment would regulate activity, enhance exposure and optimize the local condition, thereby improving the eCO2RR performance. Sui et al. [100] anchored Ag single atom with three nitrogen atoms (Ag1-N3) on a porous concave N-doped carbon (Ag1-N3/PCNC) (Fig. 13(a) ). The Ag1-N3/PCNC catalyst exhibited the maximum CO FE of 95% at −0.37 V vs. RHE, which exceeded most previous Ag electrocatalysts. In situ infrared absorption spectroscopy identified that the Ag1-N3 single atomic site had a unique linear adsorption of *CO and could easily desorb *CO, achieving the highest CO selectivity compared with other sites [101]. This work provided the inspiration on boosting eCO2RR by tuning the active center at an atomic level to achieve a specific absorption with an intermediate. Chang et al. [58] designed an electrocatalyst of tunable molecular units in an extended COF (Fig. 13(b)), which displayed the advantageous features of both molecular and heterogeneous systems and promoted CO2 reduction to CO with high activity and selectivity. Moreover, Xue et al. [102] proposed a “ship-in-a-bottle” strategy that integrated highly active Sn(IV) sites between two adjacent Zr6 clusters in the Zr-based organic framework (NU-1000), called NU-1000-Sn (Figs. 13(c)−(f)). The NU-1000-Sn catalyst had excellent catalytic performance of eCO2RR under acidic condition, and the FE of formic acid at −260 mA cm−2 was close to 100%. Replacing the primary framework of NU-1000 with PCN-222 obtained PCN-222-Sn with the Sn(IV) site, which suggested the “ship in a bottle” strategy was potentially universal for the rational design of porous materials with efficient and controllable active sites. The reason why the catalyst using the localization strategy is conducive to the formation of C1 products originates from the fact that single atomic site prevents C−C coupling to form C2+ products [103]. The electronic structure of eCO2RR is regulated by introducing bimetallic sites and clusters as active centers, thereby regulating the selectivity [104,105]. For example, Zhao et al. [106] designed a metal-organic framework (CuSn-HAB) with a heterometallic Sn-Cu dual sites (a pair of SnN2O2 and CuN4 sites brided by μ-N atoms), which attained a FE of 56.2% for CO2 to ethanol (Fig. 14(a) ). In this catalyst, the SnN2O2 site exhibited a higher affinity for oxygen atoms than that of Cu site. This enhanced affinity played a pivotal role in facilitating the generation of key intermediate *OCH2 [107]. The heterometallic Sn-Cu dual sites were more thermodynamically favorable for the asymmetric C−C coupling between *CO and *OCH2 to obtain ethanol. Li et al. [60] constructed a copper selenide electrocatalyst on porous carbon derived from a Cu-based MOF (Figs. 14(b)−(d)), which significantly improved the selectivity of C2+ products in eCO2RR especially for ethanol. At a partial current density of −229.5 mA cm−2, the FE for C2+ products reached about 85.2%. Operando infrared spectroscopy and DFT calculation showed that the formation of surface Se vacancy brought neighboring two Cu+ atoms closer and activated the Cu site, which effectively generated key intermediates (*CO and *CHO) and reduced the C−C coupling barrier (Figs. 14(e) and 14(f)). 5 Summary and outlook This review summarizes recent advances in porous catalysts for improved electrocatalytic eCO₂RR. Diverse methodologies to fabricate porous catalysts, where the metal active sites for eCO₂RR are porousized or dispersed within the porous matrices, are introduced. Equipped with the designed micro- and mesoscopic cavities, these porous catalysts demonstrate exceptional performances in eCO₂RR, regarding activity and selectivity towards the specific products. The features of pore, aperture and cavity are judiciously employed to achieve efficient enrichment, modulate microenvironmental pH, stabilize key species, facilitate mass transfer and diffusion, and tune the nature of active sites (Table 1 ). Though promising advances have been achieved for eCO₂RR fulfilled by porous electrocatalysts, the current efforts are still far from satisfactory concerning the precise fabrication of porous structures, the insight of structure-property relationships, as well as their practical applications. To further unleash the potential of porous structures in eCO₂RR for pushing industrially accessible catalysts forward, more endeavors are required. First of all, controlling the porous morphology is a prerequisite for concluding an unambiguous understanding of structure-property relationships. For the utilization of a single type of pore to achieve improved eCO₂RR, it is wise to pay specific attention to the size and distribution density of pores within the catalysts. In this case, using controllable chemical templating synthesis may be the best choice. For the construction of hierarchically porous composites involving more than two distinct sizes of pores, the order on the spatial distribution needs to be emphasized, where the electrochemical deposition of catalyst precursors onto the template is feasible. In addition, advancing green and simple synthesis methodology compatible with large-scale production for precise porous structures will be a great plus. Second, harnessing the synergy through a cross-scale perspective in the porous catalysts is an intriguing factor in determining how far we can reach to maximize the efficiency of eCO₂RR. In the microscopic realm, especially for metal active sites dispersed on the porous supports, the inter-site distance is believed to dictate the reaction pathway to alter the product selectivity. As for micropore-mesopore coupling in the hierarchically porous catalysts, more attention should be paid to the effect of the spatial relationship between the pores on mass transfer. Third, enriching the toolbox to accurately describe pore structure models and real mass transfer behaviors within porous catalysts endows us with rational design principles for high-performance catalysts. The FEM must accommodate the realistic reaction conditions and take multiple factors in account, like temperature, velocity and viscosity of electrolytes, etc. Besides, the data-driven machine learning, based on the vast amounts of structural and catalytic results derived from either experimental observations or theoretical calculations, is competent to revolutionize the present trial-and-error research paradigm and accelerate the discovery of the champion porous catalyst for eCO₂RR. Fourth, sharpening the eyes to see the evolution of reaction intermediates and active sites deepens our insights into the effect of porous structure on the reaction pathway, as well as multiple weak interactions with CO2 or intermediates during eCO₂RR. Conventional in situ analytical techniques, such as vibration spectroscopy (Raman and infrared) for detecting intermediates, scattering methodology (X-ray diffraction and small-angle X-ray scattering) for monitoring the long-distance orders, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy for probing the localized electronic and neighboring structures, have been broadly adopted in the eCO₂RR field. Unfortunately, the space-time resolutions do not fit the real reactions that take place in a timeframe of ~ps at atomic- or ensemble-level active sites. More endeavors are required to develop advanced real-space imaging or spectroscopy with faster time resolution and operated under operando conditions. The combination of multiple techniques to afford multifaceted observation in simultaneous manners will be useful. Last but not least, promoting accessible porous catalysts to meet industrial application demands is imperative. The economic feasibility is utmost, with all-round cost, catalytic performance and the value of products taken into consideration. Porous catalysts with self-supporting structures, which make the widely used binder no longer necessary, are easily integrated into MEA for achieving industry-level current density and reducing the cost of product separation. In this case, more interfaces, like the one between catalysts and ion exchange membranes, are involved, necessitating more sophisticated design for mass and electron transfer. In conclusion, porous catalysts with their unique structural advantages hold great potential for application in eCO₂RR. We believe that continued efforts are essential to further optimize their performances for practical CO2 conversion using renewable electricity, eventually approaching a carbon-neutral future. Xinwei Li (National Center for Nanoscience and Technology) received his Bachelor's degree in 2016 from Luoyang Normal University, Master's degree in 2019 from Jiangxi Normal University, and PhD degree in 2024 from Zhengzhou University. He carried out postdoctoral research at National Center for Nanoscience and Technology from 2024. His research interests currently focus on new materials and energy electrocatalysis with emphasis on design of new catalysts and reaction mechanism for small molecule conversion. Zhiyong Tang (National Center for Nanoscience and Technology) obtained his PhD degree in 1999 from the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Following that, he went to Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, Switzerland, and to the University of Michigan, USA, for his postdoctoral research. In November of 2006, he joined the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology in China and took up a full professor position. His current research interests focus on assembly, optical properties of functional nanomaterials, as well as their applications in energy, catalysis, separation, and sensing.

coredata.dc:description: Facing soaring global energy demand and intensifying environmental problems, the search for sustainable energy alternatives has become imperative. The efficient conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2), one of the primary greenhouse gases, plays the crucial role in mitigating global climate change. The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) provides an effective solution for its conversion into high-value-added chemicals, promoting the development of the carbon cycle and green chemistry. Porous materials of distinctive physicochemical properties have demonstrated substantial potential in eCO2RR. In this review, various strategies of porousizing catalysts for boosted eCO2RR are briefly summarized. Subsequently, the functionalities of porous materials including enrichment effect, modulating microenvironmental pH, stabilizing key species, facilitating mass transfer and tuning the nature of active sites to improve the efficiency and selectivity of eCO2RR are categorized. Furthermore, we discuss the principal challenges confronting current electrocatalytic systems and propose future research directions. Insights from this review are expected to benefit broad communities of chemical and material research for rationalizing porous electrocatalysts and optimizing eCO2RR performances.
